The menu online was apparently only for take out, but doesn't specify that at all, nor is there an alternate "dine-in" menu on the website. When we brought it up to the host, she didn't seem phased by the issue or the fact that we were leaving, so we didn't bother to stay. 

Reservation system was a hand-written list on a scrap sheet of paper and there was really nowhere to wait for a table. Waitstaff was running around and after 5 minutes sitting at our table, nobody had said a word to us... overall seemed rather disorganized. If the front of the house is disorganized, can't imagine what goes on in the back. 

If you have patience, maybe check the place out - food might be decent (but likely not worth the ridiculous upcharge for "dine-in"). If not... probably a good idea to stay away from this one.

Also, I guess a word to whoever makes or types the menus... it's Chicken Piccata, not Chicken "Picante"... unless you're using Pace in an Italian dish.
Expensive.  Lousy service.  Truly flavorless food.  Like an Italian greasy spoon in an industrial park.

First time here and walked in to nobody greeting us at all. Stood at the front door while a gentleman was running from table to table. He then just tells us to sit down anywhere. Brings us menus about ten minutes after that. Comes to take our order and does everything at one time, drinks, dinner, the whole thing. Food comes out and it was just so-so and barely any pasta with the chicken parm. About 7 pieces of pasta.  I guess I should of just ordered pasta alone because that was better than the Chicken parm. Seemed like if you weren't a regular here you didn't fit in. We probably won't be back. Better service and food at other Italian restaurants.

By far the worst food experience I've had in a restaurant.

The good- the people were wonderful. Sweet , attentive and helpful. The bread was delicious.  The place was packed with an over 65 set. 

The Bad- the food. My chicken Marsala seemed to use canned mushrooms a flavorless sauce and the chicken was full of gristle. The seafood risotto was a sloppy smelly mess. We sent it back. We got a serving of their homemade lasagne. We ate half to be nice and threw the rest away at home. 

The food was flavorless and unappealing.  There is nothing traditional about this place.  

The people were great but Gordon Ramsey needs to fix this place.

A mom and pop storefront place in an ugly small strip mall. The dcor is tired and the service friendly but perfunctory. The lobster ravioli was smothered in way too much sauce. My friend's gnocchi looked better. That said, it is the kind of place where you can chat with friends without feeling rushed--just like at Grandma's house. I wouldn't recommend it for a business lunch though.

The night was fabulous!  The food was amazing! If you're looking for authentic Italian food with a warm friendly family atmosphere this is the place. The chef came out Pasquale is so friendly makes you feel like home.The food was so fresh.This restaurant is absolutely my # 1 choice!!!!!! Great food!!!!

This used to be my absolute favorite restaurant but they have really slid downhill in the last year or two. The specials haven't changed once in the last 3 years and the only two soups that are offered are ALWAYS minestrone and escarole.  The service has been dicey the last few times I went, stupid things like running out of bread,  and portions have been getting smaller and smaller over the last two years. Well, I went with my friend and husband earlier this week and it will be my last time ever. I'll elaborate...  

Since, a soup or salad comes with each entree, I ordered the minestrone soup. Something was off because it had a bitter metallic taste. My husband decided on the chicken Parmesan and my friend ordered the clams with linguine in a white wine sauce. I asked the waitress what was better, the stuffed gnocchi or regular. She recommended the stuffed. Well, they brought mine out and I had exactly 15 gnocchi on my plate. My friend noticed right away what a skimpy amount it was. I asked the waitress if they accidentally gave me a half order. NOPE. That was the normal amount. When Pasquale (the owner and head chef) came out from the kitchen and asked how everything was, I mentioned this. He told me "you should have told the waitress", when I said "I did on fact tell her". His response: "well.... (Long pause) ...stuffed gnocchi is more expensive." Oh really!? I spent 16.95 on this order that has no meat based or seafood in it and you are telling me it's to expensive? Well, I value my money and not being cheated and if you as a restaurant owner are going to try to pull my leg like that, then I am no longer a customer. I am DONE. My husbands parm chicken was soggy and tasted of old oil and my friend's seafood pasta had a small lake of watery white wine sauce in the bottom of her bowl. When I want Italian food from now on, I'll be bringing my business to Toscana Restaurant. Goodbye Joe & Giuseppe restaurant forever!

This place... IS A GOOD FIND. Went here with the hubs. We ordered the pizza bread for an appetizer. Hubs ordered a chicken and caper dinner plate and I ordered a seafood amazement with red sauce and linguini... not on the menu BUT they were willing to accommodate me :)

The chef came out during our meal and greeted the entire restaurant. He wanted to know how the food was and also cracked some funny jokes. 

This place is the quinescence of a neighborhood Italian restaurant, and I love it.

This place is amazing!!  We were on our way to another Italian restaurant when we got there they were closed.  Well....we decided to give Joe & Giuseppe a try after a friend recommended it to us a while ago.  It was life changing.  The clams were the best I have had in over 25 years.  The breading was so tasty and the clams the CLAMS were tender and succulent.  Then I had the lobster ravioli and again YUM that vodka sauce will be in my dreams.  If I was a prisoner this would be my last meal!  My husband had the stuffed gnocchi OMG I will be having that next time.  Then hey top off this delicious dinner with a light powder sugar cookie.  The service was fantastic and the chef Pasquale came out to talk to his diners.  My new favorite place for an amazing Italian dinner.

This is our third takeout visit.  Eggplant Parmesan and Meat Lasagna have been very good each time.  Cannellonis are great.  The veal mushroom dish was disappointing.

Very good service, but very cramped space.  If you can get there on a weekday you'll be less crowded.

I recommend the takeout and that you experiment.  You will likely discover something you like and call on as a reliable choice....those are not so common around any neighborhood.

Really DELICIOUS and FRESH Italian food.  The restaurant is very small and located in a little strip mall - but it is definitely a little gem to find!

We have dined at the restaurant and also ordered to go.  We noticed that ordering to go is actually quite a bit cheaper than dining in -- not really sure why that is, since the portions don't seem to be different at all.  Either way, the prices aren't bad (but the to-go prices are TRULY a steal, so if you live close and want a good Italian meal at home, Joe and Giuseppe's is a great pick).

My favorites are the grilled calamari (SO tender, fresh, and delicious) and the linguine with mussels in red sauce.  They are both fantastic dishes.

The service is great too -- when we dined in our waitress was extremely helpful and attentive.  They bring you a little freshly fried pastry dish dusted with powdered sugar at the end of the meal.

I would definitely recommend trying this spot out for a romantic date night (either in the restaurant or bringing it back home).

We were there on a Saturday night. We asked for Caesar salads, and we received a bland house salad with ranch dressing, with the cucumbers tasting a bit fishy.  My husband loved his steak, although expected more for the price.  I ordered  chicken marsala, which was not appetizing. The sauce was heavy and gravy-like with very few mushrooms. The chicken was almost a mushy consistency and tasted like it had been frozen and not fresh. For the quality of food, the prices seemed to be on the high side. We will not be returning.

When I walked in, the place felt very welcoming and I already had a great feeling. The workers were very nice and the owner was even more amazing. When we talked to him he was very passionate and proud about his restaurant and he had every reason to be. The four of us (me and three family members) each finished every dish we ordered. The sauce is one of the things we raved most about it. It was the most outstanding sauce we ever tasted. The desserts were just as amazing as the dinner courses. Overall, the food was phenomenal. The place itself was small and cozy, and everyone there was as happy about the food as we were. We could hear them raving to the other workers. 
This is a must go to place! You won't regret it.

Cans down one of the best Italian restaurants I've been to in the five years I have been in Chicagoland. The atmosphere is intimate with a total of 17 tables. And the owner, let me tell you... His name is Pasquale and his cooking is as brilliant as his personality.  Making it a point to visit every table and have a lively conversation, his style is as old world as his food.
At the end of the day, there are places that you will go where the food is good, and then there are places where you go that you will remember for a long time... Joe and Giuseppe will give you the unique combination of having both :-)

Outstanding as usual, great grigliata great chicken parm. And great veal Marsala, the hostess (owner) is amazing and the service is also prompt and courteous. Desert and coffee on the house are the cherry on top.  Still a great place only negative, portions have gotten a lot smaller but hey it's still plenty and the cannoli was to die for, fantastic

We went to Joe and Guiseppe based on a referral from a friend. 
Heading into this place, my expectations were way off.  I had expected an upscale Italian bistro type of place.  That's not what this is.
We arrived around 6:00-6:30pm on a Satuday and were surprised that the place was already packed and there was a substantial wait.
The good thing was that the place turned over pretty quickly.
The folks leaving were older and clearly been there for an early dinner.  I suspect that this is typical.

What Joe & Guiseppe reminds me of is old, homemade Italian dishes.  We had veal Marsala, pasta with mussels and eggplant Parmesan.
The veal was quite good with just the right amount of seasoning.  At other places I've noticed that Marsala can get overly salty.  Not the case here.  
The mussels were excellent. Large and fresh, they swam in a light tomato sauce with some traditional Italian spices like oregano, basil etc..
The eggplant parm was a bit disappointing.  Overly bready and a bit soggy with a tomato sauce that verged on orange versus red in color.

So, here's the thing, everything was good.  Not exceptional, but solid.  The tomato sauce is not the bright red, tangy, "just picked" kind of sauce you will get in more upscale restaurants.  And that's actually good too.
J&G is really more like what you would have been served when visiting your friend's house and his mom invited you to stay for dinner.

So, I've recalibrated my expectations and really do recommend Joe and Guiseppe.
Go in expecting home cooked Italian fare that will make you think back to your childhood.

Good stuff, we'll be back.

I was a regular customer at Joe & Guiseppe for years but recently not so much. First, don't even think of trying to get a table in this tiny restaurant without a reservation. You will be stuck standing outside or crushed near the front door waiting for a table if you don't have a reservation and on weekends they've actually told us a table was not a possibility. Second, this is not a quiet restaurant. On a recent visit we inquired twice about the incredibly loud banging that never stopped and were told it was the dishwasher. Between the banging dishwasher and your fellow diners in a small space, this is not a restaurant for easy conversation. 
However the food is consistently good and the service while not attentive is friendly. They will not rush you through your meal and portions are large. There is no bar but glasses of wine are poured generously. Owner Pasquale is often found mingling with his customers and is easy to talk too when he's not in the kitchen. 
Recommended for take out or for dinner on weeknights after 7:30 pm.

As others have said, this is a very homey, authentic Italian restaurant. The owner, Pasquale, is Sicilian  so the menu consists of more southern Italian dishes. The restaurant itself lacks ambiance and its location in an ugly strip mall on an industrial part of Arthur is less than ideal. But it more than makes up for these negatives in its food and warmth. My husband always orders the 'grigliata' (grilled seafood) and really likes it. He's Parisian so is very particular about his food. I've had various chicken and pasta dishes and found all to be 'ottimi'. They serve complimentary fried dough dusted in powdered sugar and its really light, not at all greasy. They sell this dough at Mariano's but Pasquale's is so much better. We had an Italian neighbor growing up who used to make batches of this and call all the kids in the neighborhood over. Pasquale's reminds me of that. They also grow their own herbs out back and Pasquale has brought us samples of soups with some greens he grows.

It's getting rarer and rarer to find owner vs. corporate restaurants and we try to support these assets to the community. You leave Joe and Giuseppe's feeling good, not empty as you sometimes do after going to some chain ethnic restaurant.

This has been our favorite local Italian restaurant for a few years so we decided to have them put together our wedding dinner. We rented out the restaurant on a Sunday evening for a dinner of around 50 people It was perfect. The owners had their staff ready to meet all of our needs. The food was excellent, the service to our guests went above and beyond expectations. Near the end,Pasquale (head chef and owner) came out and was entertaining those that remained with stories of his vegetable garden. A great time was had by all,and we thank Pasquale and Margie for their attention to detail, their excellent food,and overall service to us and our guests.
Great food and service.  Really enjoyed the minestrone and escarole  soups.  Excellent shrimp scampi.  Good atmosphere for Grandkids, who loved the gelato!

This is by far the best italian restaurant I have ever been to. This is home cooked italian food at its best in a small, family owned restaurant. The owner often comes out to great people and his wife, the hostess is incredibly kind and welcoming.

Personal favorites:  BAKED CLAMS. best i've ever tasted, and I order baked clams everywhere I go. 
Lobster ravioli: simply incredible. The vodka & shrimp sauce is very sweet and tangy.
Chicken and eggplant parmagiana are great too.
I could easily eat an entire meal of dozens of baked clams. 

All in all, amazing food in a cozy and friendly environment.

Love this place agree the best Calms ever had. Baked or with pasta all are Great .
The owners are wonderful and make you feel at home . A Super find I have eaten here over 20 time and continue to go back and bring friends and most have loved it as much as me.

Absolutely the best Italian food I've had in my life! I love this place for so many reasons. It's a small, family owned restaurant with a great atmosphere. The owner and chef, Pasquale, makes it a point to come out and greet every table (and bring fresh baked cookies at the end of every meal). My go-to dish is the Seafood Risotto; I can't even begin to describe how delicious it is! 

If you haven't gone to this restaurant yet, you absolutely have to. You will love it.

i really liked being here! it's located in the middle of a strip mall so it's kind of hard to find. i came here with a friend who is a regular. everyone here was was super nice and it's just a cozy comfortable place to be.

the bread is warm and delicious and i loaded up on it and the olive oil and parm on the table. yum. i had the mushroom and peas risotto and it was decent. nothing good or bad about it. but it was reasonably priced and the portion was HUGE. my friend had the eggplant parmesan, which is also huge. if we hadn't stuffed ourselves, those easily could have been three meals (including the salad that came with).

they were also super nice about the salad here! i asked what kind of salad it was and our waitress was really nice and asked if there was a part of the leaf i preferred or if i had anything specific that i liked or disliked. i really appreciate how nice that was and the veggies themselves were very fresh. another thing i appreciated was the timing of everything. i didn't feel rushed at all and was not left waiting either. overall, this is just a nice little place!

Really good traditional Italian food. Mussels linguine - more than 21 mussels, I lost count.  Veal portofino, great and genererous.  Seafood risotto - ample, filling and delish.  We also had an appetizer, Grigliata - awesome.  Grilled shrimp, octopus, calamari, eggplant and zucchini.  You get soup or salad with your entree, small side of pasta witht the veal.  Complimentary portion of beignets after dinner.Needless to say, we brought half our dinner home.  

Come early or make a reservation, it gets crowded quickly on a Saturday evening and it is not a large place.  Definitely good value  and nice dinner for the money.

My new favorite Italian restaurant!!!  Not a fancy place but the food is authentic and delicious.  The red sauce is fabulous and lobster ravioli is wonderful as well.  Veal marsala is also excellent.  Great lunch specials too!  Nice touch too that the owner/Chef makes the rounds and is very personable and welcoming.

stopped in for lunch with 4 business associates around 12:30.  Took the waitress 10mins to greet us (not even with a smile) and she basically through us the menus.  Then another 10mins went by nothing, no contact, no drink order nothing.  Ended up getting up an walking out.   Hopefully the owner is reading this.  You just lost probably a $150 tab by your awful service.  Really need to improve this because your food is good.

Favorite Italian restaurant in the area. It is family owned and the size of the restaurant is relatively small but that is why it is comfortable as we can 'talk' (some restaurants are just too noisy to talk and enjoy atmosphere.) Egg plant parmesan is my favorite. Their red sauce is just fantastic. I tried a few times to mimic the sauce at hone but.... Very friendly, cozy place to enjoy dinning experience.

The food here is good...some dishes are really good like the calamari/octopus/shrimp app and the lobster ravioli. But the service is beyond bad...so bad I don't think we'd go back, which is a shame since it's so close. I've been there 3 or 4 times over the last 2 years and I've yet to have a good experience with a waitress. 

On my most recent visit we had some bread and had our water glass refilled before I had to ask someone if we had a waitress. If I want my dining experience to last 2 hours I want to do it on my own accord, not because it took the waitress 20 minutes to bring us the check (and 20 more minutes to run the credit card...)

I feel bad giving a 2 star review to a neighborhood restaurant but terrible service is too hard to overlook.
Great bread, Lobster ravioli, clams with white sauce and angel hair! Ok service. Gross spinach soup. I would go back, it's so cute and they are good at birthdays.
The eggplant pram was mushy.  The sauce thin and unseasoned. Will not eat in or take out again.
Best Veal Parmesan I have ever had. We went last night with the in-laws and everyone just loved their food. The prices are reasonable and the staff is very friendly.

I went here with my family for dinner after we decided to try some place new.  The location was kind of odd for a restaurant. It seems to be mixed in with a business district.  

The inside was cozy.  There were a fair amount of people there and it was not too noisy where we sat which was nice.  

We all came to the conclusion that the food was just ok.  It was fresh, but the taste could have been better.  

I checked the website menu before I went there and it does not seem to match the one we had at the restaurant. The choices are different and the prices are higher.  

The service was ok.  The food did not come out very fast, but that gave us some time to talk.  

At the end they do give you complimentary fried dough with powdered sugar.  

Overall it was ok, but I would not rush back.

AuthenticAuthenticAuthentic. Sicilian. They make homemade pasta noodles in the kitchen. I love this place. food seems a bit pricey, until it comes to the table and its on a 14" dinner plate and you realize you cannot eat that much food! owner is very friendly and like to talk to people who are interested. he also has a habit of passing out random things to the guests, such as slices of watermelon, or deserts. after the meal, you get a complimentary portion of beignets (powdered sugar dusted, fried batter, like funnel cake). service is usually good, but they are usually very busy. great place for an anniversary.

Manga!

A few weeks ago I had the pleasure of celebrating my Aunt/Uncle's 50th wedding anniversary.  It was a wonderful event and one of the most glorious parts was the delightful smell that came through the house when the catering order arrived.  Lasagna, spaghetti, meatballs, all kinds of delights!  The smells and tastes reminded me of the homes of friends/family with Italian moms instantly bringing me back to my childhood.  Flash forward to yesterday.  My cousin and I decided to go to dinner.  I just had to check out the restaurant.  What a great place!  We got there around 8pm on a Thursday so it was not too crowded.  We were immediately sat down and brought water and menus.  The waitress informed us that some fresh baked bread would be out shortly.  Oh boy, this was going to be great!  The place is small and charming.  It seemed like the kind of place where everyone kind of new each other.  Also, someone Pasquale (owner/chef) knew was on the XFactor, America's Got Talent or one of those kind of shows so everyone was drawn to the TV which made the evening more interesting.  We enjoyed many delights...
Fresh baked bread (complementary with our meal)
Bruschetta
Minestrone soup
Cheese ravioli with bolognese
Cheese ravioli with spicy marinara
Meatballs
Cookies with powdered sugar (complementary with our meal)
Hazelnut gelato
Tiramisu
Cannoli
I know this seems a little excessive for two people but, I really wanted to try all the delights.  We really chowed down and took home lots of leftovers.  Already ate them for breakfast!  If I wanted to save money I would skip appetizer, dessert and the side of meatballs and would still have a full meal.  That being said with all we ate and one glass of wine our bill was $62.02 which I thought was very reasonable.  This did not include the Hazelnut gelato which Pasquale gave to us complementary as he knew my cousin.  Before we left he said a very friendly good bye and I could not help but, give him a hug for such a wonderful dinner.  I can't wait to go back with my husband for date night.  BTW-if you have kids who are picky eaters like mine, they do not offer a kids menu.  My kids are super picky but, I probably still could take them here and have them fill up on bread and dessert.  They would just rather go to a place that offers chicken fingers.  Those silly boys.

Decent food and good service.  Not sure that top quality ingredients are used or that all dishes are prepared with equal attention and care, but the owners are very nice and it is a fun cozy restaurant.  It is not not the best in the area, but it is a nice family owned business that is definitely worth a try.  You may like it.

This is a wonderful family restaurant. Pasquale is the best. He walks around and greets the diners. His flare for story telling and cooking wonderful food just makes this place the best.

This was my grandpa's favorite restaurant. He would go 2-3 times a week and that says a lot when a Sicilian chooses a favorite. It's the best!

We came here for  our first date in 2014 because one of my co workers recommended this place, so we decided to try it. It was a pleasant experience. But for the 2nd experience...not so much. I came here for dinner with my boyfriend and  we got greeted at the door and sat down at our table. No one came to ask us if we wanted drinks or anything,my boyfriend had to ask a waitress to get him something to drink. Then we waited for OVER 20 MINUTES and NO ONE came to serve us. I had to get up and tell the host that we haven't even ordered our food yet. She apologized and got someone to serve us and then mentioned that we would get free desert. Now the waiter that served us walked by our table a handful of times and ALWAYS turned her head..then had the nerve to say that she "didn't" know that we were her table! Ha! Now, my boyfriend is African American and I have NEVER EVER HAD SUCH BAD SERVICE IN MY LIFE. It shouldn't matter the skin tone of someone, we came to YOUR restaurant to eat and YOU should serve us. I have never ever experienced such a thing..to wait and have a bunch of waiters walk by our table. I am completely disgusted and will never consider coming back to this place nor will I ever recommend this place! This wasn't our first time and will definitely be our last! And the food is okay,not amazing like most reviews say.

Calamari was perfectly cooked. Just enough breading. They serve it with a cocktail sauce and I would have preferred marinara. Our server suggested a great red wine and our meals were straight-up awesome! Both of our entrees were so huge there were about 4 portions for a moderately hungry person. Eggplant parm was great and fettuccine siliciane was also fantastic! The pasta was cooked perfectly. 

The downsides: it's a really cramped, tiny dining area. We felt like we were at a big family dinner which was fun but not a romantic place. I also saw several of the kitchen staff go into the bathroom with their aprons on which is pretty gross to me but the food and wine were so good I can overlook it.

This is our favorite restaurant. We love to take our friends here because they love the home made food.  My husband always gets the giambotta (Italian sausage, peppers, onions and potatoes).  I love to get the eggplant parmesan.  
It is always tender and delicious. Sometimes I get the Sicilian appetizer and have that for my meal since it is so big (and still take home half of it).
One of our friend's favorite dish is the chicken ortolano.  Another friend loves the lasagna.  The bruschetta is to die for - though the home-made bread that comes with the meal is great, also.  The minestrone soup is so tasty.  And the desserts are delicious - though we rarely have room. The owner, Pasquale,
comes out when he can to greet people but his tiime is very limited since he is the chef.

We had a large anniversary party and had it catered by Joe & Giuseppe.  I am SO glad we did. We ordered lasagna, sausage with peppers and meatballs.  Everyone raved about it.   It was such a highlight of our evening.  They do a HUGE take-out service.

It's a hidden gem I must say! The people were extremely friendly and the food was delicious! I'm very picky with Italian food and this place hit the spot! My daughter, who barley eats her food, finished her spaghetti before I was even half done! We will definitely be going back!

Absolutely excellent and authentic Italian. The waitress was very attentive and beyond nice.  We loved that the Chef stopped by the table several times during our meal, too. We had the linguini with clams and lobster ravioli.  We couldn't decide which was better so we just shared both. Both were delicious. The Tiramisu is the best I have ever had. I had the pistachio gelato that was excellent, but I kept dipping into the wife's tiramisu.

I went to eat there a few days ago and we had the bruschetta (amazing) the minestrone soup was awesome, Im going back today to get it. The entrees were good, but the best part was how nice the owner and our waitress were. I will definitely be back!
The atmosphere is great and the food is not bad.

We were looking for a new Italian place in the burbs and came across this on Yelp, so we decided to try. It is in a small strip mall off of the main road, but pretty easy to find. Once you walk in, you see that there are only a few tables and the the crowd was definitely quiet and over the age of 40. We were told to seat ourselves.

There were two waitresses working (it was a Thursday night), but you could not tell because the service was great. The meal starts with freshly baked (or in my guess, rewarmed) bread with oil on the table for dipping. The bread was great!

We skipped appetizers this time because were in a little bit of a hurry. I had the Fettuccine Giuseppe, which is chicken strips (not fried) in fettuccine with a great white wine and what tasted like broth sauce. It was SO good. My wife had the lobster ravioli and not only cleared her plate, but was dipping bread into the sauce afterward because it  was delicious! Also, they each came with soup or salad. She got the salad and I got their minestrone (which was also very good).

There were several other dishes that we were deciding between, which means we are definitely have to go back. I do not know much about wines (yet) but they had a two-page wine menu attached to their regular menu.

It was a nice touch when the chef came out to talk to us. That is always refreshing in any restaurant. I would definitely recommend this place and will be going back again. Our total bill for the two meals (soups and salad included) and a glass of wine was $43ish.
Authentic, homemade, delicious! Was surprised by this place since its in a strip mall. Go early because it fills up fast. Will definitely be going back soon!

Joe and Guiseppe's is our favorite Italian restaurant!!! We have been going there for years and its Excellent! We usually go with our  family and they Love it. We usually start with the grilliata that's always a must, if you like calamari, octopus, shrimp,eggplant,and zucchini grilled you have to try it. For dinner we usually have the linguine with Clams, or Calamari. Also the Chicken Marsala, or the Chicken Parmesan. The owner Pasquale and his staff are Great! We do all are children's parties here, Pasquale is very accommodating. It's a Great Italian restaurant and even better right in the neighborhood!!

So, I have a tendency to distrust any restaurant in a strip/mini mall.  I don't know why, but I go in expecting the worst.  I was very pleasantly surprised by Joe and Guiseppe.

The menu is mostly basic Italian comfort food - pastas, as well as several meat and seafood dishes.  Two of us had pasta with marinara and a side of Italian sausage, one had the lobster ravioli, and I had the eggplant parmesan.  Entrees come with soup or salad, and we all opted for salad with creamy garlic dressing (note: they don't normally have the garlic dressing, but the waitresses will whip it up for you - and it's great!).  All our entrees were generous portions, and very well done.  We were far too full to order dessert, but they served up a complimentary plate of cookies.  

While the place was VERY busy starting at like 5:30 on a Saturday night, the service was great, and the staff never made you feel rushed.

Should I find myself back in Arlington Heights, I would definitely make a return trip to Joe & Guiseppe's.

This is a happy, friendly place.  Waitresses are kind and helpful with menu choices.  At times, the chef comes out of the kitchen and mingles with diners.  

The dishes my family and I have tried there have been delicious.  I can't remember the names of the dishes but they've included the veal plate, the lobster ravioli with vodka sauce, linguini with shrimp, tilapia, as well as some other pasta dishes.  I loved the appetizer with the octopus and squid.  The seafood has been fresh and has not let us down.

If you save room for dessert, you should try the tiramisu.  It's perfect!

A couple of my coworkers recommended Joe & Giuseppe's. My boyfriend ( who is Sicilian) and I went around PM on Friday.  It was very crowded but we were seated right away.  

We started out with the calamari ($14.95 which I thought was a little high). A couple of bites into the dish I thought it was very fishy tasting. My boyfriend agreed. We debated sending it back ( I always feel bad!) but the chef's wife (owner maybe?) came by and asked how our dish was.  I told her that I thought it was fishy. She asked if we would like something else.  We declined (my stomach was upset now). She took the dish away and came back to tell us she was taking the dish off our bill. She said her husband (the chef) had tried it and said it tasted fine. She than said &quot;I just think it's you.&quot; I was in shock that she would say something like this to her customer. 

The rest of our meal came out.  Both our dishes were good. Nothing exceptional but I am sure that the rudeness affected the rest of my meal. I was so embarrassed that I just wanted to leave.

We love this place!  I only wish I lived in Mt. Prospect or Arl Heights.  The ambiance is wonderful, the owner-chef will come to your table to make sure you are happy.
Food is wonderful.  We went twice this Spring and service was excellent.  Prices are reasonable.  We can't wait to go back!

Phenomenal Family owned authentic italian food.  I have been coming to joe and giuseepe for probably 10 years now and love it.  The hostess is the owner along with her husband how is the chef.  They are extremely nice people who run a wonderful restaraunt.

All meals are great.  My wife lovest the lobster ravioli.  The veal is outstanding along with the chicken dishes.  Everything is fresh and made to order.  Try the calamari as a appitizer hand battered and fresh just like it should be....If you have not been here go its worth it.  IT is a small restaraunt sometimes crowded worth the wait.

Nice service but the food its not that great. I was thinking that a restaurant like this would be better than olive garden and its not its really not. The chef or owner went to all the tables to see how everything was except mine so I felt a little discriminated, but the worst thing was the food. Their marinara sauce tasted like caned tomato sauce. Wont be coming back:-)

This is a wonderful neighborhood restaurant that is tucked away in a small strip mall.  Do make reservations especially on Friday or Saturday evenings.  We went at 6 pm and they were already full with a 1 hour wait.  

Very few restaurants in the US serve octopus.  Chef Pasquale's version is just as good as I have had in Rome.  A bonus for me was escarole soup which was a comfort food from my childhood.  The fish is perfect: moist and slightly underdone.  Skip dessert for dinner as Italian cookies, fried dough dusted with powdered sugar, is included.

Prices are very reasonable and this certainly is one of our stops when we have people from out of town.
I only have one word to describe the food here..ORGASMIC! My fav Italian restaurant hands down..Lobster Ravioli is simply breath taking and also LOVE the Italian Giambotta.

I used to go here a lit as a kid and remember liking everything. Went there last night for the first time in years and was not impressed. When we get there it was busy at 8 pm we did get seated right away but then the host thought it was more important to talk to a freind about a stiry then give us menus. So we were brought water and bread before the menus that came 10 mins after we git there. The waitress didn't show up until 5 mins after that.  I had the garden salad with the "house" dressing which consisted of evoo and red wine vinegar. There was a pool of rwv at the bottom. Way over dressed. There was no other seasoning to the dressing at all no pepper or any other herbs.  I got the chicken parm with mosticcoli.  There was more breading then chicken it was so thin. Salernos is way better u can tell there is chicken. The pasta was fine but there were no ridges on it so the sauce doesn't stay on. My husband got the chicken vesuvio and i did like that but not a big portion of chicken for 15.95. Our bill was $46 with tip with 1 soda. Overall not a pleasant experience and i doubt i will go back.

We go out to eat an average of 6 nights per week and this was by far the worst service and food we've had in a long time. Several years ago we went here and it was just ok (again, had issues with the service) but we decided to give it another try. It took over an hour to get our food, things were done incorrectly, we had to hunt down the waitress (too many tables in her section) and when the food finally did come, it was mediocre at best. The only positive from the whole experience was the owner's wife. She came over an apologized and seemed very sincere. I am the first to write a good review, however I felt this deserved one star at most. Save your time and money and go somewhere else. Even a Fazoli's is more appetizing.

My wife and I ate there last Friday evening. I only live a mile from the restaurant and had never been there before. We had the best meals there, I had the Veal Piccata and my wife had the chicken Marsala. Both meals with desert was $40.00. We would not hesitate to go back again.
This place has excellent food and the service is fantastic, some of the best Italian food I've had. I would definitely recommend this to anyone looking for a good meal.

This is probably one of the best Italian places in the area however, the experience was just awkward. Everything we ordered was delicious but every time we looked up the owners/workers were staring at us. We wanted to go back for the food but my mom wasn't , 'in the mood' for that type of dining experience again. Their were also two boys that were part of the family that were arguing/fighting quite loudly for such a small place. If you're looking for some good Italian food in the suburb area I'd say this is the place, as long as you don't mind on lookers. I'll definitely venture back here one of these days.

I called Saturday afternoon to make reservation for 5 for that evening and when we got to the restaurant they had no record of our reservation. ?? This was the first sign that they don't know how to manage a restaurant. Once seated we waited almost 20 min for a waitress to even take a drink order. We asked the hostess/manager after 10 min but that didn't seem to help much. While our waitress was very nice, I'm not sure if she had too many tables, was distracted, or what the problem was. Clearly she wasn't being supervised.  We waited nearly 30 min for our check when we were finished and had to ask multiple people at least 3 times for it. Meanwhile people are lining up outside waiting for tables. The hostess should have been on top of this situation - this was a case study in How Not to Run a Restaurant 101. It took from start to finish over 2 hours for a fairly simple meal. The food was ok, some big hits some misses, but after such poor service I'm not sure we would come back. Hire a new front manager and we might be back, until then we'll take a pass.

I really don't understand the attraction to this restaurant.  We were there years ago and thought we'd try it again.  Someone from out of town was treating us to dinner, so I wanted to check prices on the restaurant's website.  When we arrived at the restaurant and I looked at the menu, the prices averaged $5.00-$6.00  higher on each entree than what was listed on the website.  Yikes!  I had chicken picante....blech...my husband had gnocchi and it wasn't very good.  Hard to hold a conversation at times, as it was very noisy in there.  Not going back again.

Always good food and was there last night again.  The cook is the owner and always comes around to see how everything is.  I would not go anywhere else for Italian and the small room atmostphere is great.

I have been to this establishment many times. This past time I brought my significant other. We had been watching an anime where the main character eats a lot of ramen, so we both had a taste for it. My partner had never had actual ramen (just top ramen) and I wanted him to experience what I can actually be like. I have been to a few ramen places (like Slurping Turtle in Chicago) but none of them compare to Ramen Misoya.

The restaurant itself is a chain from Japan, so it's safe to say it is at least a little more authentic than the posh ramen restaurants you'll find in the city. Whenever I have gone there's been at least a 10min wait to be seated. The inside of the restaurant is a little different than most places one might be used to. There are the typical table seating areas, but then there is also bar seating. The bar in this case isn't alcohol related, but instead you're sitting around the area where the chefs are cooking the food. When you walk in to be seated the chefs all yell to welcome you in as a Japanese tradition.

The menu is not extensive but you don't need it to be. There are 4 different types of ramen, and every once in a while they will have a special ramen that isn't typically on the menu. As for the different types of ramen, you can't really go wrong. Each one of them tastes delicious, but you'll want to read the ingredients to make sure you're getting something you want. Some come with potato wedges, some with clam, others with corn. The main attraction in each dish is the broth. Each ramen choice has it's own flavor of broth. I personally prefer the Hokkaido ramen which has a rich savory miso flavor. The Kyoto ramen is good if you prefer a sweeter broth, and the Tonkotsu is good if you like a fishy broth (from the clams). I've only ever had the Nagoya once, but I can't remember how it tasted. I know it was good and not at all bad like I was expecting (the flavor on the menu is described as bitter) so do not be afraid to order it.

My tip is to 100% get the extra noodles option. It's a cheap add on, but it makes a big difference if you're looking to be stuffed when you finish the ramen. Adding other ingredients to the ramen off their list is fun too, but I prefer to just order the ramen as its "Cha-Shu" version. This adds 3 pieces of extremely tender and very delicious pork to the soup. It makes the price more expensive, but I find that it is worth it if you really want to enjoy the ramen to its fullest.

Overall I love this restaurant and if it was closer to me then I would be eating here weekly. Nothing beats coming here on a cold day to be warmed up by some delicious ramen. I hope that Ramen Misoya starts to open up locations elsewhere. I think this place could be a mega hit in the city.

Shiro Miso Char Siu for the win. Got the spicy and it was powdered spice instead of paste this time. My last visit was during the winter so I'm not sure when the spicy version changed. It packed a punch regardless. 
I was excited to see that they had Tsukemen. However, asking the waitress a couple questions, it doesn't sound like what I've had before. I didn't see it on any tables so can't be sure. The waitress said that it was the same noodles as the ramen, didn't know if the broth was prepared differently and didn't come with lime. 
I'll give it a try on a future visit but was in the mood for a proven winner with the Shiro miso. Side note: despite putting my name down twice, they crossed my name off without calling my party. Had a 15 minute wait at 12:30 Wednesday.

Great ramen!!! I had no idea ramen could be so good - don't let the college type fool you! Huge portions, different varieties including vegetarian.

Small inside but they move you thru fast or you can get it to go.

Misoya was a favorite of mine for awhile until i found Strings in Chicago. Personally they are both really up there for me. I prefer strings over misoya but if i needed my ramen fix i wouldnt mind going to misoya. 

I say try something different. It a great shop with lots of options and pricing is killer. Not gonna break your wallet type of price. 

I always get extra pork because i love the taste. 

People are nice and typically on weekends long line so go around lunch time if you have the chance.

Good luck and slurp up some noodles!

This is not the hipster ramen that you may have been eating. Misoya has locations worldwide and Michelin recommended. For around $12 a bowl, it's no wonder this place has 45 minute wait times. 

All of the broths are miso based hence the name, Misoya. Each broth varies with the use of white, yellow, and red miso so be prepared. This is a thicker broth that tends to be stronger in umami and overall saltier than your lighter clear broths. For added toppings, make sure to get their famous cha-shu which is thinly cut marinated pork belly that's been grilled. 

Get the tonkotsu ramen. It's a broth cooked with pork bones for 15 hours that produces a rich creamy unctuous broth. It's so rich that you'll be able to taste pork fat on the top of your mouth afterwards. You won't see this type of ramen broth often since it takes a long time to cook and intense piggy flavor. 

Be healthy and eat your miso.

I was very excited for ramen when I came here. But even at 1:30PM on a Sunday, there was a wait. We waited about 20-30 minutes before we were seated. 

I ordered the kyoto style ramen and takoyaki. The food came pretty quickly and I started enjoying my meal. But I think they're A/C was broken that day because it was veryyyy hot inside. And as I was eating the piping hot ramen it started to become uncomfortable. The ramen was delicious and the soup base was flavorful and not too salty. I didn't like the chashu as much...it wasn't as tender as other ramen joints. I ate about half my bowl due to the heat and couldn't eat anymore without feeling sick. 

The takoyaki had more filler than actual octopus. The flavor with the sauces were good though. 

Overall, not a great experience but I attribute it mostly to the A/C not working..and I couldn't fully enjoy my meal.

I was battling to give it 2 or 3 stars. I'll state my reasons below. Again I'm writing as someone from out-of-state and have the privilege of enjoying a good bowl of ramen anytime in LA. I can't help it but be really critical. 

Located in a very dark neighborhood with not much street lights. The night was drizzling and cold. Perfect moment for ramen. Waited for over 30 mins to get seated. 

Comment by stars: 
-the Asian lady host was so friendly with every customer. Her smile and hospitality are probably why many pple keep coming back. (4 stars)
-Got the Hokkaido Ramen: was pre-warned it's very salty. Heck, the soup base was rather salty. I was upset by the thickness of the chasu pork. I noticed the grilled marks may have led the meat to taste a bit tough and not as tender. (2 stars)
-Potato wedges in the ramen: I'm not a big fan of potatoes, but still why would you want to ruin a bowl of ramen by throwing in 2 large potato wedges?? (1 star)
-Chicken karaage: I actually like this dish as it did taste like chicken. Many places tend to over deep fry it. (3 stars)

Parking: small lot.

I was planning on going to Mitsuwa to pick up some items and yelped the area to see potential lunch spots. This place was one of my many bookmarks for the area so decided to swing by around 11:10 on a Sunday and saw around 10 people in line already for their 11:30 opening.  At 11:43 the restaurant was about 90% full.  

 If you're not familiar with ramen just know that this restaurant has a few different ramens for those who aren't exactly sure what to get.  Want more vegetables in your ramen? There's a bowl for that.  Want more spice and extra chashu? There's a bowl for that.  The broth is salty goodness and the noodles are just the perfect chewiness.  Ramen to me is one of those mystical food items.  I'll know when it's horrible but for the most part, I love every kind and don't over judge such a simple dish.  Once you start dissecting it, you'll miss out on the food experience.  Just eat the damn bowl and accept the fact that the magical bowl of ramen that a lot of critics are comparing every bowl to is probably doesn't exist.  Or they were really drunk when they ate it and you know, everything tastes awesome when you've had one too many IPAs.  

I ordered the spicy Tokyo ramen with an added egg (a must) and a small order of chicken karaage. I'm not sure if it's because I was starving at this point but the chicken karaage had lots of flavor.  It was salty and perfectly fried with a light batter and served with a delicious creamy sauce to dip it in.  Definitely paired well with my bowl of ramen, which you can guess was also perfect. I'm excited to take ramen noobs here just because there is a variety to choose from.

My whole lunch was $17 and it was sooooo worth it.  I wasn't expecting a wait when i pulled up but understand why there was one.

Stopped by this place with another fellow Yelper since we were in the area.

This place specializes in various types of miso ramen.  There's actually a store location in NYC around Saint Marks that I'm aware of, but unfortunately I haven't had the chance to visit that one.

I ordered the Kome cha-shu ramen.  The portion was extremely generous (3 large slices of cha-shu) and the noodles were cooked just right.  However, the broth was simply too salty for my palette.  Just for reference, it's definitely not the first time that I've had miso.  I get that it's naturally salty, but this was just too much for my taste.  The cha-shu was also too tough and salty as well.

I actually only ate less than a quarter of the bowl and had to abandon ship after that...  Maybe I'm just not cut out for miso ramen...

If you like your food on the salty side, perhaps this place would be good for you...

If you want variety, come here! I was pleased to find pages worth of miso ramen here. It took me and my husband 10 minutes to decide what to order (most of it was because I was being indecisive, but still... lots of options!). If I was rating this place solely on their ramen noodles, it would get an easy 5 stars. The noodles are a bit thicker than the usual, but has great consistency. Now the broth is where things got a little disappointing for me. I ordered the 'Spicy Tokyo Miso Tonkotsu' which was not quite spicy for me, but more on the salty side. The broth was also a bit greasier than I had liked. Maybe the other ramen choices are better? Not sure if I would come back to try out the others... It's close enough to Mitsuwa (less than a 5 minute drive), but if I had the choice, I would choose Santouka Ramen at Mistuwa food court instead.

We also ordered a side of gyoza which was also a disappointing 'meh'... ramen shop gyozas are my favorite, so I do tend to get a bit picky especially with its crispy-ness. I can tell you this place had no crispy-ness but a lot of soggy-ness. 

FYI... the cha-shu (pork) slices are HUGE here, unlike other ramen shops. I saw that the 'Tokyo Miso Tonkotsu' came with one piece of cha-shu (seems typical for most of the ramens to come with one), but I ordered another slice thinking one wouldn't be enough. I was SO wrong!! The slices are not only big, but also thick so one should fill you up very quickly!

We love coming to Misoya.  We get:

- fried shrimp
- chicken karaage
- agadashi tofu 
        The breading is really light.
- chasu pork ramen
        There are three pieces of pork and the broth is really flavorful.
- Pork fried rice
- green tea ice cream with red bean

There are various options to order on the side with the ramen e.g. tofu, fried shrimp, etc.

The service is phenomenal.  The server gives me a hot tea and my wife ice water.  They give us two forks.

This is in a small strip mall with limited parking.  You need to get there before it opens for the seating is limited.

I love that this place is open until 10pm.  Often my husband doesn't get home from work until after 7:30.  

This tiny little hole in the wall is really close to our home so we just had to try it out.  I love soup and ramen is pure comfort food.

My husband ordered their Chicken Karage and pot stickers with a side of steamed rice.  I had the miso ramen with vegetables and ground pork.  While he didn't care much for the pot stickers he did love the chicken a lot.  My ramen wast really tasty - a touch on the salty side... But just a touch.  I absolutely love their miso egg topping.  Perfectly done.

It was a big portion too.  No way was I going to be able to finish it.

Definitely a do-again restaurant!

If you are serious about your ramen this place is a must visit.  Seating is limited and I have heard there are usually long wait times, but the two of us came a bit after 7pm on Sunday night and were seated right away.  That being said, when we left the waiting area had filled in quite a lot, so we may have lucked out!

They have a very specialized menu focusing on miso-based ramen.  There are a variety of sides and appetizers, but for mains it is ramen and nothing but!  You can get Hokkaido, Kyoto, or Nagoya-style broth with the same four basic ramen dishes, or you can get tonkatsu ramen if you don't want any of those.  For our first trip we stuck with the more basic Kyoto ramen.  My husband is the bigger ramen fan between the two of us and he described it as amazing and as good as what we had in Japan.  While I am not the biggest ramen aficionado I agreed it hit the spot.  When the craving for authentic ramen strikes again Ramen Misoya will certainly be top of mind.

Can't say how much I love this place.
Went here with the love of my life, on a date, when I went to go visit him. Now the only type of ramen I've ever had is maruchans top ramen (which is not only super bad for you, but its shit compared to this).  We had an itch lately to have ramen: first, because it's one of his favorites; and second because we've been watching Naruto and that boy eats a lot of ramen - and makes it look so damn good.

This place is a little pricer, but not by too much. I suggest getting everything in your ramen, and ORDER EXTRA NOODLES! I know it's a whole $1.50 more, but then you get a shit ton MORE noodles, which makes it soooo much more worth it! I also got the eggs, for extra, and they tasted good - nothing special, but it adds another element to the soup.

Now the thing I enjoyed about eating ramen, for the first time, is all the variety in the bowl!!!!
1. the potatoes are SO FREAKING DAMN GOOD!!!!!!!!!!! (you get them only with select ramen bowls)
2. the eggs (additional cost) are good too, and add an element of taste and texture
3. ground pork is OKAY, not a huge fan - didn't add or subtract from flavor to me
4. bean sprouts are DA BOMB, love em love em love em
5. ramen itself was delicious
6. pork chops taste so wonderful - try eating these slowly

See, variety! Lots of variety in one bowl.
Perfect for dates. Service is good (though there's a preference for asians - they get speedier service). Prices are good. Wait times are good, first come first served. Small restaurant, so there's usually a line - sign up when you walk in and they'll call you after a short while.

Definitely a favorite, and I highly recommend!
Was a cool place, very wide selection.
WOW Magical place here. I cannot recommend this place enough.!

They make ramen they way I like it.   A thick, oily broth with a ton of fried pork to kick up the flavor.   No wimpy soup here.

Prepare to wait as the restaurant is pretty small and there are not many tables available.
Get the delicious fried chicken app, & any of the yummy ramen! I like the spicy ramen the best.

Slurp. Slurp. SLURP. I'm not trying to be rude. Just being respectful to let them know that I'm enjoying my meal. Ramen Misoya has fresh wavy yellow ramen noodles with a perfect springy bite. It's the real deal here! 

Reading material while I sit at the communal counter bar waiting for my food to come out with an atrocious cold and runny nose. (I am terribly sorry for the couple sitting next to me if they got sick later that week.)

Point 6. Green onion miso soup is effective in fighting the cold by allowing excessive heat to be released. Perfect!

Other health benefits:
- eliminates those pesticide coated foods we eat
- reduces allergies (No more sneezing, itching, watery eyes, stuffed sinuses)
- miso is good in digestion (I feel a bowel movement going...or maybe I'm just too full)
- prevents cancer?! (another reason to eat more)
- miso fermentation = essential vitamins (No more popping multivitamins, kidding!)
- strengthens immune system (I feel like this cold is neverending...)
- removes heavy metals from the body, including radiation? (Detox. detox. detox.)
- antioxidant - prevent dementia & Alzheimer's (Maybe it'll help with my forgetfulness.)
- increases metabolism and blood flow (Sweat it off. Less working out. Reason to be lazy.)

Order's up!
Tako yaki app:
6 crisp on the outside and gooey on the inside ping-pong sized balls stuffed with an octopus cube topped with shaved bonito flakes and seaweed sprinkles dressed in mayo and a sweet takoyaki glaze. Yum!

Hokkaido style (Kome miso) chashu ramen for him:
Stronger/fuller bodied broth. That pork! So divine! Perfectly charred on the grill, more meat than fat, 3 slices medium thickness. Crispy potatoes gave it a nice texture. Very generous portion for under $13. 

Kyoto style (Shiro miso) yasai ramen for me:
Lighter/natural broth. Ground pork with lots of veggies (although, I think they forgot to put a scoop of corn in mine like the menu says, now that I look at it!) Love the tofu puffs which soaks up the miso broth like a sponge. Cabbage, I could pass on. I highly regret not getting the chashu with it at this point. I thought it was going to be flavorless, fatty, mushy pork like I've had at other places.

Note for next time: Get extras like the miso egg with the perfectly cooked yolk, crisp tofu, and butter. Those few $ are totally worth it.

I had pretty average expectations for Ramen Misoya since the menu seemed so limited and it was out in the burbs. Proved me wrong for sure. Looking forward to our next visit!

Got a shrimp tempura miso ramen here for dinner which was a 5 minute wait since it is a very small hole in the wall shop. They served us water while we waited and service was very good! The waitresses were nice and polite. My soup had a deep nutty flavor which was described as a bitter miso in the menu but it tasted fine. The broth was saltier than I usually prefer and this was my first authentic ramen place I've been to, in Cleveland I would go to the fusion ramen place known as Noodlecat, which their kale salad is my go to from now on :). My ramen came with 3 tempura shrimps and some veggies, the chestnuts I didn't care for. Also it had some pork in it. I know there are tons of ramen places I need to try but this place was not bad! 3 stars because they only have 4 ramen choices though.

The ramen was excellent and the service was great. For the the location it was really small so when coming during lunch time it'll be packed. There will be a wait but worth the wait. 

The ramen had 3 types of soup base. The menu is descriptive on the taste so you will know what you are ordering.

 Overall it's a place you should try and give your own opinion cause mine is that it's a place to try.

Ordered Shiro style cha shu ramen, fried squid, and fried chicken. The fried chicken didn't seem to battered with potato/corn/sweet potato starch, as crispness was bit lacking. However chicken and ramen were both well seasoned. Squid lacked saltines and came with no sauce. 

I would go back to try other food and will update.
The chashu is very very good. The noodle is ok. But the soup base is so salty. That's the most salty ramen soup I had in my life.
Solid Ramen.  Especially for the price point. We arrived at 5p on Saturday....several open tables.  Service was excellent, with plenty of helpful suggestions.

My friends brought me here when I came back to town to visit. This place has some of the best ramen I've tasted. I hate that you have to pay like $1.50 extra for a freaking egg but it wouldn't be the same without it. We also got an appetizer or calamari and the fried chicken. We dashed a little bit of curry powder on the chicken (which they charged us an extra $0.50 for) but it was so good! Lightly battered but fresh and crunchy. The calamari was lightly battered as well, tender and flavorsful. Not too chewy. The noodles in the ramen were so fresh and the broth in it was amazing. A little of the salty side but not over powering. 

It definitely gets hot in this place. Not sure if they have AC? So when it's hot outside, you can bet it's hot in here and humid. Seating area Is small, very small. They have maybe 5 tables that seat 4 at each and of course the bar top. Very little room to move in. They have a little waiting room with chairs to sit at while you wait for a table to ready for you. Of course, a fan blowing in case it's hot haha! Definitely worth the wait though.

I had the kome miso #1 char-su ramen and the broth was really salty. My friend got the spicy broth and that was quite delicious. The noodles were a bit thick and very chewy but the pork, bamboo shoots, and egg were delicious.

The atmosphere is great though. I love the bench around the bar/kitchen area.  It reminded me of a traditional restaurant in Japan. The server is incredibly nice and helpful too.  

If I go back, I would try the tonkotsu ramen since I'm hoping the pork bone based broth won't be as salty.
Not that I know what 'good ramen' is comparatively, but DANG I liked this place.  I was by myself and sick with a cold and still enjoyed the food and atmosphere, so that's worth something.  Tasty!

So in Illinois, not a lot of ramen places exist compared to San Diego. When we yelped ramen and I picked out this place we were singing hallelujah. The spicy ramen tonkotsu is the best! Their ramen bowls are truly worth the money you spend! For the first time ever my husband took home leftovers, yeah, they serve you that much! 

The servers are also very nice and are helpful, they could tell it was our first time and helped us choose. The space inside the restaurant could get cramped but we went on a Saturday around 2 with no wait. 

I feel like I would be able to eat their ramen everyday! Now only if it was more closer to Kenosha :(

I've had this place Bookmarked fo-eva, so was super excited to try it. 

I've only had "real" ramen a handful of times. There were 3 different styles, so we asked about the difference, and were told that the first two pages were what we should probably go with.

I ordered a spicy ramen (Hokkaido style I believe), which was okay, but perhaps I shouldn't have stirred the chili in, since the spice ended up overwhelming every other flavor. The pork was good. The three pieces of tofu were good. The two eggs I ordered were good. There were very few veggies: a few pieces of bamboo shoots and green onion (where are the bean sprouts and corn?). The only plus is that I had enough leftovers for lunch the next day.

As far as appetizers, my +1 had mentioned something about some sweet potato fries offered at Japanese ramen places.  I didn't see them on the menu and asked (nope), so we ordered the fries as they were listed on the menu. I was thinking they'd have some interesting twist:  maybe battered in tempura?  Side of Qupie mayo? Turns out they were nothing more than plain wedge fries served with ketchup. Skip those. Totally, totally skip french fries! Why are normal french fries even offered?!  Madness; gahhhh!

The octopus balls were plentiful with drizzles of eel sauce (?) and something else.  They were very hot and pretty delicious, but the octopus inside was very tiny. 

The guy (owner's son?) who took our order was friendly and personable when he was at our table, but that persona immediately switched off as soon as he left.  I like when service isn't overbearing, but he wasn't even checking on patrons: I never once saw him scan the dining room to see if anyone needed anything.  I was looking in his direction multiple times to see if I could cue him that we needed boxes and the check, but nothing.  I ended up having to catch him - before he walked by again - after he was at the table behind us.

The seal of this 3-star deal was the dirty bathrooms. I can understand a toilet maybe being defiled by a previous patron and going unnoticed, but the floor was dirty.  If you don't mop your bathroom floor, how can I trust you're cleaning your kitchen?

I had such high hopes for Ramen Misoya based on all of the glowing reviews and pictures, but feel I got the short end of the stick.  So disappointing!

We finally followed the Ramen hype and got to try it here. The service and food was just superb. The staff was all smiles and came to check on us at the right times. The Ramen broth was the perfect saltiness to my liking. The broth, pork, noodles and veggies complimented one another that it was hard to put down my fork and spoon. I added shrimp which I took out and placed to the side right away to avoid it was getting soggy. It was a nice touch since it added a slight crunch to the savory soup. 

I was a bit skeptical since the waiting area wasn't the nicest, but my mind quickly changed upon walking into the restaurant. While it was rather small and simply decorated, it was very   clean and welcoming. 

A few tips: go a few mins before it actually opens b/c a line forms rather quickly. They have a sign in sheet right past the first door. Review the menu ahead of time to save time once seated.  Seating is limited and the largest table only seats 6, so limit your party size. Come hungry as the bowls are fairly large and very filling.

Excited to go back and try more.

This is one of the BEST ramen places in the world.  My favorite order is shiro miso spicy with extra spicy with 3 peice pork for ramen, and a large side of chicken karage.  Another good suggestion would be go during off peak hours, however if you considering going during when its busy the wait is never more than 20-30min atleast in my experience.  If you know of these very good little restaurants, there is a good reason why they are busy and that there is a wait. The staff is incredible, a must visit if your in the area

Went here based on some Reddit reviews of the best Ramen in the Chicago area.  They didn't disappoint.  Absolutely the best Ramen I've had stateside.  I've had dozens of different places and styles and this is the best.  

One thing of note is the choices.  It's only about 5 different ways.  But the add-ons make it customizable, but be wary adding too much destroys the taste and will up the price significantly.

I had the spicey, and for me it was perfect.  Just remove some spice paste before stiring, you can always add more if it's not to your liking.

I'll be back, that is for sure.

I'll be honest, idk what all the hype was about. 

It is a restaurant with limited seating. I think I only got a seat so quickly because it was right after lunch time and it was just me. The waitress was very pushy to get me to order and I found out she didn't even give me a whole menu because she gave a complete menu to the older Japanese couple next to me (mine didn't even have a cover and was tattered). She asked me 3 times what I wanted to order and then u didn't hear from her again until she gave me my check. 

I was talking to the guy next to me and we didn't know if it were due to the meat sweats or the fact that we were literally right next to the kitchen (over the counter) that made it so hot while eating. Made the experience almost uncomfortable. 

Food was comprable in price to what I've experienced at similar locations. It was decent tasting food  although it did come a bit salty. 

Tbh, I wouldn't mind eating here again if I were in the area, but I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here.

I've been wanting to try this place for awhile based on the good reviews.  So one cold night in  January, my husband and I dropped the baby off at my parents' and off we drove to Mt Prospect to see what the fuss was all about.  I was prepared to wait but I did not expect the wait to be in a cold (no heat), cramped, fluorescent-lit hall with folding chairs.  (At least there were chairs). The wait was around 45 min which normally I would skip and go someplace else, but since we made the trip to Mt. Prospect, we stuck it out.  When we finally got seated, we were attended to quickly but waited awhile for our ramen bowls.  I ordered the Kome Miso spicy ramen with an egg.  It was pretty spicy and real salty which I'm not a fan of but I read that the high sodium in ramen isn't bad for you. I slurped mine within minutes since I was so hungry.  
The restaurant is small which explains the long wait.  They may want to consider expanding the space to accommodate more people.  Overall, the ramen is good, but expect to wait up to an hour if you go on a weekend night.

Ehh. The ramen has good flavors but it is too salty for my taste. The portion is generous but even pork pieces have too much fat on them. And the shrimp had that frozen shrimp taste when I bit into it. I am probably being picky but all in all not as expected. I really liked the corn croquette though

Great noodle!  Decent price. Just make sure don't come at lunch or dinner time. Even on Sunday!  Especially if you are already hungry. The wait is always very long!!!!

Very friendly staff. Speaks English, Japanese and Chinese. :-)


This time getting something a little different. Pork plate and fried rice.  Also very yummy!!!!!!

Love this place. 

Staff is friendly as usual, food is fast as long as you come in right as they open, or else you will have to wait because it's so popular.

Food: good
Services: good
Price: fair 
Environment: okay
Distance: okay 

I only been there with my friend for 2 times. The service was good, and their waitresses were very sweet!

My friend brought me there when I was sick. I didn't not have good appetite to eat anything, so we share a bowl of ramen. After I had my first bite, I started eating a lot and ordered more food. It was too good and helped me to eat some food when I was sick!! It's amazing!

Small place, great ramen selection and very well executed. Filled with Japanese eaters during our lunch, usually a good sign for a ramen place.  

Enter, put your own name on wait list. Food came fast, hot, good. We ate at the counter and there are also 5-6 tables. 

3 adults ate for $48 plus tip.

I should give a 3.5 if possible. I will go back to taste more to update my review.  Got Komemiso veggie ramen, which was pretty good but the other Miso Tonkotsu was a bit over cooked taste or somehow niboshi like taste (if they use Niboshi in Tonkotsu a bit uncommon to mix...) bitterness.  Anyway, I will be back !

Ive worked near this area for over 5 years and yesterday was my first time ever going here. Its pretty easy to miss as its tucked away in a small strip mall away from the busy street. 

I was pretty impressed with my lunch. I ordered a vegetarian ramen. The potatoes on top of my ramen were amazing. I could have just ate a bowl of that and I would have been perfectly happy. The portions here are very generous. Way better than going to Mitsuwa, it puts them to shame. 

Im looking forward to my next visit and venturing out into some ramen with seafood.

Amazing Ramen!  We ordered three different types - Cha Shu (Mame), Spicy Ramen (Shiro), and Regular Ramen (Shiro).

They were all delicious and extremely flavorful.  We loved it.  Their servings are HUGE!  Especially after having multiple appetizers, pot stickers and squid balls.  

We will be back - I just wish they were closer - they're upwards of an hour from my house in the far northwest suburbs.  If they were closer, I would be here at least twice a month!

I slurpped all the way to cloud 9 when I visited the infamous Ramen Misoya...and I would be more than happy to slurp up this deliciousness over and over again in the future!  I guarantee that when I am in the mood for some ramen I will definitely be trekking to Ramen Misoya as opposed to any other joint for some of that delicious diaretics  (I'm not being gross, guys, ramen really is awesome for you to eat when you are not feeling so great if ya know what I mean).  

Speaking of, Ramen Misoya had many signs posted around the restaurant, informing people of the several benefits to eating ramen.  Although a benefit is that ramen cleanses you, just remember "cleansing" means you're gonna be lettin' some rip...so make sure you're not in a confined space.  

Aside from the practical benefits of ramen it's also just damn delicious!  I don't think that it particularly matters which kind of ramen you order, especially since all of the three variations of ramen are similar and equally good.  For me, I honestly couldn't identify the major difference between the three types of ramen that could be ordered but I promise you will be satisfied with whatever you order. Apparently the primary difference is the way the ramen is prepared - I'm still clueless as to how this preparation differs from one to the other but just ask someone who works there.  

Now I feel bad but I can't remember the actual variation of ramen I got, but I do know that I got shrimp instead of the famous pork in my ramen.  I will admit that in person the pork looks good, but seeing as how I didn't get the pork in my ramen I can only talk about the shrimp which was amazing.  I'm a shrimp fanatic and will most likely enjoy it in any meal, but it's quite tastey when mixed with the ramen.  I loved this ramen, though, because there was so much to enjoy in just one bowl...it took me forever and a day to eat, or rather slurp.  The flavors all mixed together was amazing and the ramen was perfectly salty...and hot! 

Also, we got the octopus appetizers which was amazing!  They were rubbery with a perfect twist of crunchiness - so perfect!  The appetizers and two large bowls of ramen was only about $35 which is quite good considering the enormity of the bowl itself!  You get a great deal for the amount and quality of food  you're getting.   

The only complaint that I may have is that there is very limited seating and the space is quite small.  I believe that this place has grown in popularity which is why the space is too small for all of it's frequent flyers.  and this place truly does have frequent flyers -  a testament to how good and reliable Ramen Misoya is.

Great place for a Ramen for sure. Just one complaint was that I asked for a vegetarian menu, i was given one, I ordered from that menu and gave me a regular Karaage Ramen, so disappointing. I should've reiterated that it needed to be vegetarian with the substitute for the meat that was indicated on the vegetarian menu as well as the soup.

After my trip to Momofuku in NY I was craving some ramen!!!!! 

There isn't really anywhere quite near me and I wanted to make sure I was getting' the good stuff so I decided to make the trek. It was worth it! 

Once our waiter knew we hadn't been there he explained the different types of ramen and made a couple suggestions. I went with a spicy seafood one - with the spicy sauce on the side and it totally hit the spot. 

Plus, the serving size is huge and the pricing very reasonable. I will definitely be back again!

FYI it's a fairly small place, so you may need to wait a bit for a seat. I'd try to go at off peak times.

This is really a 3.5 star ramen establishment, but I had to round up since yelp does not offer a half star.   The ramen noodle had a nice texture and bounce. The grilled pork topping was flavorful. The egg was perfectly cooked. Rest of the toppings including corn, bamboo, bean sprouts, seaweed, etc. were pretty much standard. The problem was the broth. Kome was SO SALTY that the complexity of the miso was lost. The rest of the ingredients simply tried to dampen the blow without success. Salt was simply mistaken for flavor. Shiro was a little less salty and taste did shine through. Best of the three was the Tonkotsu. Still salty, but not enough to totally hide the complex mix of pork fat and miso. Unfortunately, I did not try the Mame. This ramen shop is definitely worth a try. I wanted to love it, but the extreme saltiness downgraded what could have been an awesome bowl of ramen.

Everyone I know always rave about this ramen joint and I finally got a chance to give it a try! 

Cha Shu Ramen: What I really enjoyed the most was the noodle. Not sure if it's house made or not but it's great! This ramen came with a lot of things inside of it. Compared to other ramens I had, their portions of meat is greater which it better. Unfortunately, I wasn't able to enjoy the broth like I was hoping too. My taste buds are sensitive to salt and I felt that they broth was too salty to my tasting. 

The service was very attentive and I appreciated that. The waitress was so friendly and nice. 

Hopefully, I can come back and give other dishes a try but it's so far in the burbs.

It was such. a. long. wait. and I was starving when I went there for dinner, but with the huge portion of ramen it was so satisfying. 

Ramen in it's nature is salty so be sure to drink a lot of water, and the waitress/ waiters are quick to attend to you. The place is very small as well so I don't recommend for groups and you most likely will have to sit bar side. 

They will also adjust some of the bases for their ramen to accommodate vegetarians.  

I think the best time to eat here would be in the winter because a nice warm bowl of Misoya ramen hits the spot.

Not my favorite, but if you're nearby... 

I came years ago and didn't care for it the first time. I've had a few more bowls of ramen since then, so thought I'd give it another go. Definitely better this time now that I know what I like and what to order.  

We ordered the chicken karaage (fried chicken app) and the fried shrimp app. I loved the shrimp but the chicken was plain. It was better with sauce but I probably wouldn't order it again. 

I forgot what ramen I ordered the first time I came, I think it may have been the Hokkaido style, but now I know that I love tonkotsu broth so I got that this time. I added pork and an egg (always do if it doesn't come with). The broth was great! I still don't care for the consistency of the noodles or the pork texture, but I'd come back!

Bottom line up front: the ramen here is amazingly good. 

I lived in Japan for three years and my favorite restaurant was a Hokkaido-style ramen shop not far from my house. The kome ramen here at Misoya has theirs beat, and that's no easy feat. I've never had anything like the chashu here -- they grill it and it comes out with nicely browned grill marks that impart an extra level of deliciousness to what's already a scrumptious, melt-in-your mouth meat. As an extra touch, they also add a wedge of fried potato to the top. Don't forget to add the miso eggs -- perfection!

Now for some cons: as others have said, there's frequently a wait here. Our party of four arrived just after noon on a weekday and we ended up waiting nearly an hour. Part of this was due to a clerical error on the part of the hostess. You have to write your name and number in your group in a book at the entrance.
